newsitem.title: USA: PRESS DIGEST - NZ Business weeklies - July 4.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - NZ Business weeklies - July 4.

text.p: Big-six accounting firm faces actions: Top accountancy firm Price Waterhouse has faced dissatisfied clients three times in court this year. The cases have involved former and current Wellington partners. Page 1.

Auditor-general called in over police projects: The auditor-general is considering investigating alleged police tender mismanagement of multimillion dollar computer projects after receiving the Serious Fraud Office's file. Page 1.
Government broadcasting review runs over deadline: The government's review of its television services, expected to be completed by last Monday, could take another two months. Page 3.
Public Trust goes for life planning: Public Trust, New Zealand's oldest state-owned financial institution, is to launch a Plan for Life scheme as part of a major push into financial planning. Page 9.

Government's GST fiddle leaves TV funding body with drastic shortfall: New Zealand On Air, which gathers and distributes the broadcasting licince fee, pays an amount equal to its administration costs to the Commerce Ministry, which counts it as revenue before sending it back as expenditure. Page 12.

Government refuses to be rushed on labour market reforms: New Zealand government ministers do not share the view they need to quickly embark on the set of radical new labour market and social policy reforms, outlined by the Employer's Federation in a report entitled 'Towards Full Employment'. Page 15.

Accusations fly as winebox inquiry winds up: In an apparent trial run of arguments expected to be advanced in the High Court early next year, lawyers for the IRD and the Serious Fraud Office lined up alongside the corporates named in the winebox documents this week to attack counsel assisting the Commission of Inquiry, Colin Carruthers QC. Page 1.
Cut-price computer man crashes again: For the second time in less than two years cut-price PC dealer Mark Mahony has left creditors in the lurch. Page 1.

Infratil advances in Argentina, Germany: Listed utilities company Infratil gained ground this week on two fronts: in Argentina where it is after a slice of the Post Office and in Germany where it is bidding for a 50 percent stake in Dusseldorf Airport. Page 3.

Orchardists get pip, lose power: The Fruitgrowers Federation this week snatched back from the Pipfruit Growers Inc, the apple growers' industry body, the power to select two out of seven representatives on the Apple & Pear Board. Page 3.
Luxton calls on cockies to throw down statutory arms: Commerce Minister John Luxton is calling on cockies to disarm the Dairy Board and remove its statutory marketing powers. Page 4.
Telecoms users target Commerce Act revamp: Reforming the Commerce Act is top of the lobbying agenda for the Tellecommunications Users Association (TUANZ). Page 5.

Ostrich punters plucked: Jeff Meltzer, liquidator of failed ostrich investment company Savannah Ostrich Processing Company, this week sent out a statement of affairs saying a payout to creditors was unlikely. Page 6.
Kiwi salmon farmers tackle Aussie import ban: New Zealand salmon farmers and the government have relaunched their battle against an Australian quarantine ban on fresh salmon imports. Page 6.
